content:
The passage below is from a essay written by a well-known novelist of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.
There is a certain evening that I count as virtually a first impression- the end of
a wet, black Sunday, twenty years ago, about the first of March. There had been an
earlier vision, but it had turned gray, like faded ink, and the occasion I speak of was
Line
a fresh beginning. No doubt I had a mystic prescience of how fond of the murky
5Babylon I was one day to become; certain it is that as I look back I find every small
circumstance of those hours of approach and arrival still as vivid as if the solemnity
of an opening era had breathed upon it. The sense of approach was already
almost intolerably strong at Liverpool, where, I remember, the perception of the
English character of everything was as acute as a surprise, though it could only be a
10surprise without a shock. It was expectation exquisitely gratified, superabundantly
confirmed. There was a kind of wonder indeed that England should be as English as,
for my entertainment, she took the trouble to be; but the wonder would have been
greater, and all the pleasure absent, if the sensation had not been violent. It seems
to sit there again like a visiting presence, as it sat opposite me at breakfast at a small
15table in a window of the old coffee-room of the Adelphi Hotel-the unextended
(as it then was), the unimproved, the unblushingly local Adelphi. Liverpool is not a
romantic city, but that smoky Saturday returns to me as a supreme success, measured
by its association with the kind of emotion in the hope of which, for the most
part, we betake ourselves to far countries.
20It assumed this character at an early hour-or rather indeed twenty-four hours
before-with the sight, as one looked across the wintry ocean, of the strange, dark,
lonely freshness of the coast of Ireland. Better still, before we could come up to the
city, were the black steamers knocking about in the yellow Mersey, under a sky so
low that they seemed to touch it with their funnels, and in the thickest, windiest
25light. Spring was already in the air, in the town; there was no rain, but there was still
less sun-one wondered what had become, on this side of the world, of the big white
splotch in the heavens; and the gray mildness, shading away into black at every pretext,
appeared in itself a promise. This was how it hung about me, between the window
and the fire, in the coffee-room of the hotel-late in the morning for breakfast,
30as we had been long in disembarking. The other passengers had dispersed, knowingly
catching trains for London (we had only been a handful); I had the place to
myself, and I felt as if I had an exclusive property in the impression. I prolonged it, I
sacrificed to it, and it is perfectly recoverable now, with the very taste of the national
muffin, the creak of the waiter's shoes as he came and went (could anything be so
35English as his intensely professional back? it revealed a country of tradition), and the
rustle of the newspaper I was too excited to read.
I continued to sacrifice for the rest of the day; it didn't seem to me a sentient1
thing, as yet, to inquire into the means of getting away. My curiosity must indeed
have languished, for I found myself on the morrow in the slowest of Sunday trains,
40pottering up to London with an interruptedness which might have been tedious
without the conversation of an old gentleman who shared the carriage with me and
to whom my alien as well as comparatively youthful character had betrayed itself.
He instructed me as to the sights of London, and impressed upon me that nothing
was more worthy of my attention than the great cathedral of St. Paul. "Have you
45seen St. Peter's in Rome? St. Peter's is more highly embellished, you know; but you
may depend upon it that St. Paul's is the better building of the two." The impression
I began with speaking of was, strictly, that of the drive from Euston, after dark, to
Morely's Hotel in Trafalgar Square. It was not lovely-it was in fact rather horrible;
but as I move again through dusky tortuous miles, in the greasy four-wheeler to
50which my luggage had compelled me to commit myself, I recognize the first step in
an initiation of which the subsequent stages were to abound in pleasant things.
						
The speaker in the passage can best be described as a person who

						

						
						

						

						
Correct Answer: B

						
Explanation:

						
(B) Not only is the speaker similar to a memoirist, he actually is one, fondly recalling his arrival in England about twenty years before (line 2) when he was still "comparatively youthful" (line 42).

content:
The passage below is an excerpt from a book written during the 20th century.
In Massillon, Brown's rules had served as a sort of social welfare, teaching high-school
boys to develop self-control and discipline. In Cleveland, his dress codes, his curfews, and
his strict study regimen with playbooks, constant lectures, and testing, served a different
postwar ethic: it enhanced an image, the image of a well-run organization.
5His model turned out to be less a throwback to wartime army discipline than a look forward
to a new style of corporate control.
"We want you to reflect a special image in pro football," Brown told his players in a
speech at the opening of each season.1 They were not to smoke or drink in public; they were
 to wear jackets and ties, slacks and polished shoes in public; they were to display
10a proper "decorum" and not curse in public; if they so much as lounged on the ground
during a game, they were fined; above all, they were never to behave in a manner that
would make the team look "low class"-in other words, that would remind anybody of the
league's origins in the mills and mines.
Brown demonstrated the seriousness of all this at the first opportunity: two days
15before the new league's first title game, he fired the team's captain, Jim Daniell, after
the tackle had a few drinks and got into a minor spat with some local policemen. "I'll
take my players high class, cold, deadly," Brown repeated in his seasonal speech. "We don't
want any butchers on this team. No T-shirts in the dining hall. Don't eat with your elbows
on the table and eat quietly." He told Time magazine in
201947, "There's no place on my team for Big Butch who talks hard and drinks hard. I like
a lean and hungry look." When a young college lineman whom Brown was planning to
recruit arrived at the team's training camp unshaven and "dressed like a laborer,"
Brown took one look, told him that he had been summoned mistakenly, and dismissed
him at once.2
25"Class always shows," Brown maintained, and what he wanted his men to show was the face
of the new, white-collar bourgeoisie. "I didn't want them to look like the stereotype of
the old-time pros," Brown said. "College players had a good reputation, but the public
perception of the professional football player back then was of a big, dumb guy with
a potbelly and a cheap cigar. That kind of person disgusted me, 
30and I never wanted anyone associating our players with that image."3 What Brown
wanted was a managerial look: polished and uniform, college-educated but not effetely so,
aspiring but conformist. What he wanted was a team represented by organization men. It was
the sort of look he himself exemplified. With his contained demeanor, trim frame,
and bland corporate suits, he looked like the archetypal suburban
35husband about to board the commuter train to his desk job in the city. While Brown
was insistent on his men flying first class and staying in fine hotels, it turned out
this was not so much for their sakes as for the public profile of the team. He was intent
on turning pro football into a sort of respectable middle class occupation that fit with
the new white-collar bureaucracies and the rising corporate management
40ethic of postwar America.
1 Brown, PB, p. 148.
2 Ibid., pp.16, 148; Clary, Cleveland Browns, p. 18; "Football: Brown Ohio," Newsweek, Dec. 30, 1946, p. 66; Byrne, et al., The Cleveland Browns, p. 17; Maule, "A Man for This Season," p. 32; "Praying Professionals," Time, Oct. 27, 1947, pp. 55â€“56.
3 Clary, The Gamesmakers, p. 32; Clary, Cleveland Browns, p. 19; Brown, PB, p. 15.

Which of the following best states the subject of this passage?

answers.B: <label>B. The role of a football coach</label>
answers.C: <label>C. A football coach's vision of his team</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The transformation of professional football teams</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

(C) Although an element of each choice appears in the passage, the main focus is on Coach Brown and his effort to reshape the image of the players on his team.

Which of the following rhetorical strategies does the author use in paragraph 1 of the passage?

I. parallel syntax

II. repetition of sentence structure

III. antithesis
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

(E) Parallel syntax is exemplified by the series phrases in lines 3 and 4. The structure of the first two sentences of the passage is virtually identical: Both begin with prepositional phrases, and both contain the same verb, served. The last sentence of the paragraph employs antithesis (not a "throwback" but a "look forward").

Which of the following best describes the rhetorical function of the second sentence (lines 2–5) of the passage?

answers.A: <label>A. It amends the tone of the first sentence.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. It puts an idea expressed at the start of the passage into different words.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. It presents a specific example in support of the preceding generalization.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. It states the main idea of the passage.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) The passage is devoted to a discussion of the ideas stated in this sentence—how Brown went about reshaping the image of the players on his team.

explanation:

In line 12, "low class" implies all of the following EXCEPT
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Which of the following pieces of information can be inferred from footnote 3?

answers.A: <label>A. That all of the works listed in the footnote have been cited in earlier footnotes</label>
answers.B: <label>B. That Clary writes articles for sports publications</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) Because the works cited contain only the author, title, and page number, it's reasonable to infer that each of the works has been listed before. The previous citations probably contained full information about each work. (It's also possible that the author of the book used another documentation method in which all footnotes refer to works listed in a separate bibliography.)

2 Ibid., pp.16, 148; Clary, Cleveland Browns, p. 18; "Football: Brown Ohio," Newsweek, Dec. 30, 1946, p. 66; Byrne, et al., The Cleveland Browns, p. 17; Maule, "A Man for This Season," p. 32; "Praying Professionals," Time, Oct. 27, 1947, pp. 55â€“56.
3 Clary, The Gamesmakers, p. 32; Clary, Cleveland Browns, p. 19; Brown, PB, p. 15.

Taken all together, the footnotes suggest that

answers.A: <label>A. sports historians depend more on books than on news magazines as sources of information.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Ohio is the center for publishing books about football and other sports.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. most of the material in the passage is anecdotal.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Brown's work was a fertile source for the author of the passage.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the passage was written roughly in the middle of the 20th century.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

(D) All three footnotes cite Brown, suggesting that the author of the passage found Brown's work fruitful.

content:
The passage below is an excerpt from a book written during the 20th century.
In Massillon, Brown's rules had served as a sort of social welfare, teaching high-school
boys to develop self-control and discipline. In Cleveland, his dress codes, his curfews, and
his strict study regimen with playbooks, constant lectures, and testing, served a different
postwar ethic: it enhanced an image, the image of a well-run organization.
5His model turned out to be less a throwback to wartime army discipline than a look forward
to a new style of corporate control.
"We want you to reflect a special image in pro football," Brown told his players in a
speech at the opening of each season.1 They were not to smoke or drink in public; they were
 to wear jackets and ties, slacks and polished shoes in public; they were to display
10a proper "decorum" and not curse in public; if they so much as lounged on the ground
during a game, they were fined; above all, they were never to behave in a manner that
would make the team look "low class"-in other words, that would remind anybody of the
league's origins in the mills and mines.
Brown demonstrated the seriousness of all this at the first opportunity: two days
15before the new league's first title game, he fired the team's captain, Jim Daniell, after
the tackle had a few drinks and got into a minor spat with some local policemen. "I'll
take my players high class, cold, deadly," Brown repeated in his seasonal speech. "We don't
want any butchers on this team. No T-shirts in the dining hall. Don't eat with your elbows
on the table and eat quietly." He told Time magazine in
201947, "There's no place on my team for Big Butch who talks hard and drinks hard. I like
a lean and hungry look." When a young college lineman whom Brown was planning to
recruit arrived at the team's training camp unshaven and "dressed like a laborer,"
Brown took one look, told him that he had been summoned mistakenly, and dismissed
him at once.2
25"Class always shows," Brown maintained, and what he wanted his men to show was the face
of the new, white-collar bourgeoisie. "I didn't want them to look like the stereotype of
the old-time pros," Brown said. "College players had a good reputation, but the public
perception of the professional football player back then was of a big, dumb guy with
a potbelly and a cheap cigar. That kind of person disgusted me, 
30and I never wanted anyone associating our players with that image."3 What Brown
wanted was a managerial look: polished and uniform, college-educated but not effetely so,
aspiring but conformist. What he wanted was a team represented by organization men. It was
the sort of look he himself exemplified. With his contained demeanor, trim frame,
and bland corporate suits, he looked like the archetypal suburban
35husband about to board the commuter train to his desk job in the city. While Brown
was insistent on his men flying first class and staying in fine hotels, it turned out
this was not so much for their sakes as for the public profile of the team. He was intent
on turning pro football into a sort of respectable middle class occupation that fit with
the new white-collar bureaucracies and the rising corporate management
40ethic of postwar America.
1 Brown, PB, p. 148.
2 Ibid., pp.16, 148; Clary, Cleveland Browns, p. 18; "Football: Brown Ohio," Newsweek, Dec. 30, 1946, p. 66; Byrne, et al., The Cleveland Browns, p. 17; Maule, "A Man for This Season," p. 32; "Praying Professionals," Time, Oct. 27, 1947, pp. 55–56.
3 Clary, The Gamesmakers, p. 32; Clary, Cleveland Browns, p. 19; Brown, PB, p. 15.

The development of the last paragraph (lines 25–40) can best be described as

answers.A: <label>A. a selection of details leading to a generalized summary.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. a series of examples arranged chronologically.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. a statement of opinion followed by supporting evidence.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. the movement from theory to a factual conclusion.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

(A) The paragraph contains a number of quotations amplified by the author's commentary. The last sentence summarizes Brown's intentions and generalizes the overall point of the passage.

l

Carefully read the following passages and answer the accompanying questions. Questions 1-12 are based on the following passage from "Samuel Johnson on Pope," which appeared in The Lives of the English Poets(1779-1781).

"Shaven" and "leveled" in line 34 indicate that Pope's style of writing was

content:
Carefully read the following passages and answer the accompanying questions. Questions 1-12 are based on the following passage from "Samuel Johnson on Pope," which appeared in The Lives of the English Poets(1779-1781).

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B If it were a contest, Pope would be declared the winner by Johnson. A close reading of both the structure and the content of the paragraph leads the reader to Pope. When discussing Dryden and Pope, Pope has the last work. This allows Pope to linger in the reader’s mind. “Frequent” with Dryden and “perpetual” with Pope is another indication of Samuel Johnson’s preference.

The following excerpt is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s "Politics and Warfare," which appears in The Man-Made World: Our Androcentric Culture(1911).

The author's main purpose in the passage is to
explanation:

content:
The following excerpt is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s "Politics and Warfare," which appears in The Man-Made World: Our Androcentric Culture(1911).

In paragraph 2, the author maintains that men support their position on equality for women based upon which of the following approaches?

answers.B: <label>B. a syllogism using a faulty premise</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The question requires the student to be familiar with methods of logical reasoning and logical fallacies. Gilman presents the syllogism men use to deny women the right to vote:

Those who fight may vote.

Women do not fight.

Therefore, women may not vote.

“Those” is understood to be men. The first premise is incorrect, as is the second premise. This being the case, the conclusion is invalid.

content:
The following excerpt is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s "Politics and Warfare," which appears in The Man-Made World: Our Androcentric Culture(1911).

Using textual clues, one can conclude that "androcentric" most probably means
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E This question depends upon both vocabulary and careful reading. Paragraph 8 points to a philosophy that desires to exclude women from politics. Therefore, any political involvement must be male-centered.

content:
The following excerpt is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s "Politics and Warfare," which appears in The Man-Made World: Our Androcentric Culture(1911).

In addition to indicating a direct quotation, the author uses quotation marks to indicate

answers.A: <label>A. the jargon of politics and warfare</label>
answers.E: <label>E. that the author does not take responsibility for her words</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Most readers expect quotations to be used to indicate a direct quotation or specific titles of works. However, there are other uses for these bits of punctuation. One is to set off specific words or phrases used by others in a given context. Here, Gilman is making direct reference to the words employed by society’s male leadership.

content:
The following excerpt is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s "Politics and Warfare," which appears in The Man-Made World: Our Androcentric Culture(1911).

In paragraph 4, "increasingly injurious as society progresses" is reinforced by all of the following except :
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Because the argument of the passage is to criticize the aggressive nature of politics in a male-managed society and to point out the results of combining politics and warfare, the question demands details that support the idea of aggression being detrimental to society. The only choice that does not reflect this idea is E.

content:
The following excerpt is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s "Politics and Warfare," which appears in The Man-Made World: Our Androcentric Culture(1911).

According to the author, men view the primary purpose of government to be

answers.C: <label>C. obtaining as much power as possible</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Look carefully at the second paragraph to see the ranking Gilman sets up as the male-centered priorities. The only one ranked over the others is fighting and the ability to kill. Therefore, the only appropriate choice is C.

content:
The following excerpt is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s "Politics and Warfare," which appears in The Man-Made World: Our Androcentric Culture(1911).

The argument shifts from a discussion of warfare to a discussion of politics in the first lines of which of the following paragraphs?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Syntactically, the phrase, “Similarly in politics” is an indicator that a comparison is being drawn between what came before and what comes after. No other phrase does this.

content:

The tone of the passage is best described as
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

D Because this is an argumentative selection, the author is expected to take a position on an issue. Because of this, the choices of “ambivalent” and “indifferent” are immediately eliminated. Keeping in mind the diction of the piece, you can see that “reverent” and “condescending” are also inappropriate.

content:

explanation:

content:
The following excerpt is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s "Politics and Warfare," which appears in The Man-Made World: Our Androcentric Culture(1911).

To present her argument, Gilman primarily uses which of the following rhetorical strategies (techniques/modes of discourse)?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C If you read the passage carefully, you cannot avoid the cause-and-effect sequencing throughout the excerpt. Look at paragraphs 2, 3, 4, 6, and the last. Remember that an author can use many different techniques in the same work, but only one will be predominant, and that strategy is what reinforces the author’s purpose.

content:
The following excerpt is from Charlotte Perkins Gilman’s "Politics and Warfare," which appears in The Man-Made World: Our Androcentric Culture(1911).

"It," as used in paragraphs 4, 5, and 6, only refers to

answers.A: <label>A. Fighting is to them the real business of life [paragraph 3]</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A It is interesting to look at the singular use of this pronoun. In every instance, “it” refers to “fighting,” while reinforcing the author’s relentless focus on the essential problem.

content:
The speech is "On the Death of Martin Luther King, Jr." by Robert F. Kennedy.

The primary purpose of RFK's speech is most probably to

answers.A: <label>A. inform the people of the event</label>
answers.B: <label>B. praise the accomplishments of Martin Luther King, Jr.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. call for calm and unity between blacks and whites</label>
answers.E: <label>E. offer condolences to the black community at large</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Although RFK tells the audience of the death of Martin Luther King, Jr., and although he briefly asks the audience to pray for King’s family, condolences are NOT the focus of the speech. No real listing or praise of King’s accomplishments is given. Throughout his speech, Kennedy continually stresses the need for unity, wisdom, and compassion.

Correct Answer: C

C The paragraph is only concerned with the words of Aeschylus that are centered on the results of loss. The other paragraphs realistically acknowledge the violent history of this nation.

content:
The speech is "On the Death of Martin Luther King, Jr." by Robert F. Kennedy.

RFK most probably chose to refer to the Greeks in paragraph 11 for all of the following reasons except :

answers.A: <label>A. to impress the audience with his scholarship</label>
answers.B: <label>B. to concisely restate the theme of the speech</label>
answers.C: <label>C. to provide a healing thought for the people to remember</label>
answers.D: <label>D. to elevate the level of discourse</label>
answers.E: <label>E. to reinforce the ideals of democracy with which the Greeks are associated</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A It is obvious that RFK does NOT want to separate himself from his audience. The hope is to take the emotions of his audience and to lift them out of the realm of emotional, violent responses and to provide an avenue for peaceful and positive outlets for their grief.

content:

explanation:

content:

answers.E: <label>E. sleep is the only escape from pain</label>

Correct Answer: A

Although each of the other choices contains words or an idea that is a single part of the quotation, none other than A takes into consideration sleep, time, pain, wisdom, and God.

content:

explanation:

D There is nothing in the last two paragraphs that indicates that the purpose is to pay tribute to Martin Luther King, Jr. Therefore, D is the appropriate choice.

Nassau Point

President of the United States,
White House
Washington, D.C.

Albert Einstein

In both paragraphs 2 and 3, Einstein makes use of the dash

answers.A: <label>A. to emphasize the words set off</label>
answers.B: <label>B. as an exception to the point immediately before it</label>
answers.C: <label>C. to sound more scholarly and formal</label>
answers.D: <label>D. as an informal aside to what was said previously</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D This question requires your knowing the uses of the dash and your ability to recognize how it is actually used in a given text. Here, you should see that Einstein is making a statement that could have also been set off with commas or parentheses. It is a more informal device.

content:

Old Grove Road
Nassau Point
Peconic, New York
August 2, 1939

President of the United States,
White House
Washington, D.C.

Albert Einstein

answers.A: <label>A. Einstein expects his name alone will identify him</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Einstein assumes that the information he presents is compelling enough to command a response</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Einstein believes himself too busy and important to waste time on pleasantries</label>
answers.D: <label>D. As a scientist, Einstein was accustomed to having the facts speak for themselves</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C This is a rather obvious answer to a question that many would be tempted to “over-read.” Don’t try to make things more complicated. You should also be aware of the conventions of the letter form.

content:

answers.A: <label>A. secure Einstein's role as Roosevelt's "permanent contact"</label>
answers.B: <label>B. suggest a plan of necessary action to ensure American security</label>
answers.C: <label>C. increase research funding for further nuclear experimentation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. end scientific research leading to the construction of nuclear bombs</label>
answers.E: <label>E. send a letter of warning to Germany</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

B This is a process of elimination question. Checking for evidence to support each of the choices eliminates A, C, D, and E. Those who would point to C must look again at both paragraphs 6 and 7. Here, it becomes obvious that paragraph 6 does not contain any reference to funding. Remember, all parts of the answer must be supported by the text.

content:

explanation:

content:
Albert Einstein
Old Grove Road
Nassau Point
Peconic, New York
August 2, 1939

President of the United States,
White House
Washington, D.C.

Einstein's first paragraph suggests all of the following except :

answers.A: <label>A. FDR is not staying abreast of important scientific developments</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Einstein is concerned about how the administration is handling the new developments in uranium research</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Einstein is concerned that the administration may be unaware of important developments in the scientific community</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Einstein is an authority in the use of uranium</label>
answers.E: <label>E. FDR is familiar with the work of Fermi and Szilard</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The very fact that Einstein does not include any introductory information about Fermi or Szilard indicates that FDR is cognizant of current scientific endeavors. Moreover, there is no evidence of neglect on the part of the President. Therefore, A is your correct choice.

content:
Albert Einstein
Old Grove Road
Nassau Point
Peconic, New York
August 2, 1939
F. D. Roosevelt,
President of the United States,
White House
Washington, D.C.

Which of the following best identifies Einstein's primary mode of discourse in his letter to FDR?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D An AP Comp student needs to be familiar with the modes of discourse and must be able to recognize them. This question asks the reader to note the persuasive nature of Einstein’s letter. There is no storytelling, no directions, and no exposition or analysis.

To illustrate the gravity of the situation, Einstein uses all of the following except:
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E If you know the meaning of gravity as used in this selection, you are led to look for words that are indicative of a seriousness of purpose. This is also a question that can be answered without necessarily returning to the text. A, B, C, and D contain a common urgency and a seriousness lacking in choice E.

content:
Albert Einstein
Old Grove Road
Nassau Point
Peconic, New York
August 2, 1939
F. D. Roosevelt,
President of the United States,
White House
Washington, D.C.
Yours very truly,
Albert Einstein

Einstein understates the urgency of developing "chain reactions" in America

answers.A: <label>A. with the repetition of the words might and may</label>
answers.C: <label>C. by mentioning "other countries repeating America's work"</label>
answers.D: <label>D. with the phrase "though much less certain"</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Understatement, which Einstein uses because of his unwillingness to become an alarmist, is shown by his use of qualifying words and phrases rather than direct statements. Each of the choices provides room for Presidential ambivalence.

content:
Albert Einstein
Old Grove Road
Nassau Point
Peconic, New York
August 2, 1939
F. D. Roosevelt,
President of the United States,
White House
Washington, D.C.
Yours very truly,
Albert Einstein

To persuade Roosevelt to consider his recommendations, Einstein uses all of the following approaches except:

answers.A: <label>A. discussions with other members of the scientific community</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Einstein appeals to fear (paragraph 3), presents evidence (paragraph 4, line 1), makes predictions (paragraph 2), and offers a plan [paragraph 5, (a), (b), and (c)]. However, he does NOT discuss anything with members of the scientific community in this letter.

content:
Albert Einstein
Old Grove Road
Nassau Point
Peconic, New York
August 2, 1939
F. D. Roosevelt,
President of the United States,
White House
Washington, D.C.
Yours very truly,
Albert Einstein

In his letter, Einstein's own assumptions are all of the following except :

answers.A: <label>A. his interpretation of the manuscript is accessible</label>
answers.B: <label>B. his reputation as a scientist lends weight to his opinion</label>
answers.C: <label>C. his plan can be implemented quietly</label>
answers.D: <label>D. his urgency concerning the situation is apparent</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Germany recognizes the urgency of the situation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Assumptions are tricky questions to work with because they demand your own thoughts and conclusions from the piece. Read each choice carefully, making certain that nothing in a choice is contradictory or invalid. In this question, choice D is the only assumption NOT supported by the text. (Note: Information contained in previous questions could have been helpful in selecting your answer.)

content:
Albert Einstein
Old Grove Road
Nassau Point
Peconic, New York
August 2, 1939
F. D. Roosevelt,
President of the United States,
White House
Washington, D.C.
Yours very truly,
Albert Einstein

After a careful reading of the letter, which of the following inferences is not valid?

answers.A: <label>A. Einstein understood the urgency of addressing the nuclear problem.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Einstein assumed FDR would react to the letter.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Einstein viewed the private sector as a means of circumventing a possible governmental impasse.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The Germans could have possibly misunderstood the significance of this scientific discovery.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Einstein is suspicious of German espionage.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Inferences are NOT the same as assumptions. To infer is to reach a conclusion based on facts or observations. To assume is to take something for granted, although it is not proved. In other words, if I see you carrying an opened, wet umbrella and wearing a wet raincoat, I can infer that it is rainy outside. I could assume that you are a person who listens to the weather forecasts. For this question involving an inference, the reader cannot find proof in the letter to support the conclusion that the Germans may have misunderstood the significance of the scientific discovery.

content:
The following passage is entitled "Reading an Archive," by Allan Sekula, which appeared in Blasted Allegories, a collection of contemporary essays and short stories, published by MIT Press in 1987.

The first sentence (lines 1–3) does all of the following, except:

answers.A: <label>A. to indicate that material appears in this essay prior to this section</label>
answers.D: <label>D. to state the thesis of the piece</label>
answers.E: <label>E. to establish that the essay is based on the opinion of the author</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D This selection is not totally focused on the subject of history being spectacle. The ellipsis indicates that material preceded this given piece. The use of footnote 7 is indicative of previous research. The word this establishes the relationship between cause and effect. The word suggests and the phrase “takes on the characteristics of spectacle” are indications of opinion.

content:

"initial contexts" in lines 35–36 refers to

content:

content:
The following passage is excerpted from Charles Dickens’s Pictures from Italy.

The purpose of the passage is to

answers.D: <label>D. present the dichotomy existing in Florence</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The very first sentence indicates the author’s purpose. Here, the reader is told directly that Florence is both fanciful and somber, rich and stern.

content:
The following passage is excerpted from Charles Dickens’s Pictures from Italy.

The primary rhetorical strategy used by the author is
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B This selection is based on a quite specific description of Florence and an area within the city. To correctly answer this question, the student needs to be familiar with the different types of rhetorical strategies.

content:
The following passage is excerpted from Charles Dickens’s Pictures from Italy.

In developing his purpose, the author uses all of the following rhetorical devices except:
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E The reader is brought from the general street scene to a specific prison and then to a specific scene outside the prison. Metaphors, similes, and imagery are found throughout the selection, such as “small cells like ovens,” “distrustful windows.” Contrast and comparison are provided with such phrases as “faded and tarnished Great Saloon” placed next to the “walls which record the triumphs of the Medici.” The passage does NOT follow a specific timeline.

content:
The following passage is excerpted from Charles Dickens’s Pictures from Italy.

Which of the following lines contains an example of paradox?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The test taker needs to know the definition of paradox and must be able to recognize it in a given text. Here, smoke is being used to purify the air even though it is in itself a pollutant.

content:
The following passage is excerpted from Charles Dickens’s Pictures from Italy.

The most probable function of the selected detail which focuses on the murder of the young girl by the old man (20–22) is

answers.A: <label>A. to emphasize the brutality of the citizens</label>
answers.B: <label>B. to establish a tone of pathos</label>
answers.D: <label>D. to warn visitors about the dangers of the city</label>
answers.E: <label>E. to emphasize the contrasts evident in the city</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Dickens is not warning people away from Florence, nor is he criticizing its government. What the text and its selection of details do is to reinforce the idea of Florence being a city of contrast (youth and age, life and death, bright flowers and squalid prisons).

content:
The following passage is excerpted from Charles Dickens’s Pictures from Italy.

The abrupt shift caused by a lack of transition between paragraphs 1 and 2 serves to do all of the following except :

answers.A: <label>A. reemphasize the unexpected nature of murder</label>
answers.B: <label>B. reinforce the idea that there is no connection between the two paragraphs</label>
answers.E: <label>E. immediately whisk the reader to a place of safety away from the murder scene</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B There is no support from a close reading of the text that will allow you to defend choice B, which sees no connection between the two scenes described. Obviously both reveal aspects of Florence. Both are descriptive, with the second paragraph containing the selective contrast with the first paragraph.

content:
The following passage is excerpted from Charles Dickens’s Pictures from Italy.

What can be inferred from the following details taken from the passage

— "small distrustful windows" (4)

— "walls of great thickness" (5)

— "enormous overhanging battlements" (8)

— "secret passage" (29)

answers.B: <label>B. Florence was designed to protect its artwork.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Florence had experienced both warfare and intrigue.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Distrustful and secret are indicative of “intrigue,” and building thick walls and huge battlements points to the need for protection from aggression. No other choice provides these same inferences.

content:
The following passage is excerpted from Charles Dickens’s Pictures from Italy.

Lines 11–22 contain examples of which of the following rhetorical device?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A A close look at each of the selected lines reveals opposites being placed side by side. This is the nature of antithesis.

content:
The following passage is excerpted from Charles Dickens’s Pictures from Italy.

If one were building a house of horrors, which of the following would be best suitable as a model or inspiration?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The Palazzo Vecchio is described using such terms as “ponderous gloom,” “faded” and “tarnished” and “mouldering.” These are evocative of a place that is creepy and frightening. None of the other choices projects these qualities.

content:
The following passage is excerpted from Charles Dickens’s Pictures from Italy.

Which of the following terms has most probably undergone a shift in meaning from Dickens's time to its current usage?
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D In Dickens’s time, “jealous” was used to indicate the state of being watchful or closely guarded. If you look at the context of the line, you can see that “jealous” has nothing to do with our current use of the word.

content:

One reason Atwood gives for the presence of stories in children's lives is
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Each of these would cancel the other out, because they would be equally valid. Choice C is nowhere to be found in the selection. Therefore, the appropriate choice is D, listening.

content:

content:

The last sentence of paragraph 2, "From all these scraps …" to "forbidden knowledge," contains all of the following except :
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E If you look carefully, you find examples of all of the choices except E. An ellipsis is punctuation comprising three periods. You find none in this sentence. Its function is to notify the reader that a piece of the text has been omitted.

content:

explanation:

Explanation:

content:

According to the author, the writer is like a child because

answers.A: <label>A. We are likely to accept these stories being of the same level of reality as the kitchen stories [paragraph 4]</label>
answers.B: <label>B. … we are taught to regard one kind of story as real … [paragraph 4, next to last line]</label>
answers.D: <label>D. We will have old husbands' tales [paragraph 5]</label>
answers.E: <label>E. … the kinds of stories that are told to children have been called nursery tales … [paragraph 5]</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C This is a rather easy question. The entire third paragraph supports this idea.

content:

answers.A: <label>A. society does not value the storyteller</label>

content:
The following passage is from Margaret Atwood’s "Origins of Stories."

The predominant tone of the passage is best stated as
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Words, phrases used, and specific details given in this passage support the adjective “wistful” (paragraphs 3 and 4). She is observant throughout the passage as she provides details of the child acquiring her stories. The writer’s wistfulness is reiterated in the last paragraph as she states her yearning for men to share in the language of storytelling.

content:
The following passage is from Margaret Atwood’s "Origins of Stories."

The author makes use of which of the following rhetorical strategies?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The only choice that presents two strategies actually present in the text is B. The entire passage employs exposition to support the author’s purpose. Even the final paragraph, which attempts to persuade, uses exposition to strengthen the appeal to have men welcomed into the language of storytelling. (If you are not crystal clear about the terminology used in the choices, this may be one of those questions you choose to skip, because it can be time consuming trying to determine the correct choice.)

content:
The following passage is from Margaret Atwood’s "Origins of Stories."

A shift in the focus of the passage occurs with which of the following?

answers.B: <label>B. Perhaps this is what writers are … [paragraph 3]</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Perhaps this reflects the extent to which North American children have been deprived of the grandfathers … [paragraph 5]</label>
answers.E: <label>E. But as things are, language, including the language of the earliest-learned stories … [paragraph 5]</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The abruptness of “Traditionally,” provides no real connection with the previous paragraph or the previous sentence. It is an obvious break that grabs the reader’s attention and leads him or her to Atwood’s point.

content:
The following passage is from Margaret Atwood’s "Origins of Stories."

The primary purpose of the passage is to

answers.A: <label>A. plead for men to tell more stories</label>
answers.E: <label>E. look at the sources of storytelling</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Throughout the passage, Atwood is taking a close look at the beginnings of storytelling. Although she does attempt to persuade us of the need to encourage men to tell their stories, this is not the primary purpose of the piece. It is important to also notice that the title is a clue to this answer.

content:

content:

answers.D: <label>D. ease the reader into a scholarly topic</label>

content:

content:

content:

content:

content:
The following passage is from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa society, at Cambridge University, August 31, 1837, entitled "The American Scholar."

In line 17, the word "diet" refers to
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

content:
The following passage is from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa society, at Cambridge University, August 31, 1837, entitled "The American Scholar."

The speaker characterizes the great writers as being able to
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

content:
The following passage is from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa society, at Cambridge University, August 31, 1837, entitled "The American Scholar."

The speaker's attitude toward great writers in the fourth sentence of paragraph 1 (lines 5–8) might best be described as
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Using the process of elimination while looking carefully at the given lines, you will discover that the only answer that correctly relates to Emerson’s attitude is D. All the others are negative.

content:
The following passage is from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa society, at Cambridge University, August 31, 1837, entitled "The American Scholar."

The speaker's tone in the passage can best be described as
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Vocabulary is a key factor in this question. In this passage, Emerson is “taking apart” the qualities of a great writer, book, and college. This is what an analytical essay does.

content:
The following passage is from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa society, at Cambridge University, August 31, 1837, entitled "The American Scholar."

All of the following lines use figurative language except :

answers.A: <label>A. It is remarkable, the character of the pleasure we derive from the best books. They impress us with the conviction that one nature wrote and the same reads.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. … and some preparation of stores for their future wants, like the fact observed in insects …</label>
answers.C: <label>C. We boil grass and the broth of shoes, so the human mind can be fed by any knowledge.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. I would only say that it needs a strong head to bear that diet. One must be an inventor to read well.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Gowns and pecuniary foundations, though of towns of gold, can never countervail the least sentence or syllable of wit.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A In the first two sentences of paragraph 1, Emerson is setting up the parameters of his argument. There is no figurative language here.

content:
The following passage is from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa society, at Cambridge University, August 31, 1837, entitled "The American Scholar."

After reading the passage, the reader can infer that the author desires to

answers.A: <label>A. praise the work of current writers</label>
answers.B: <label>B. change the curriculum of the college</label>
answers.D: <label>D. warn against relying on academic appearances</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Carefully reading the last paragraph, especially the last three sentences, can only lead you to choose D. None of the other choices is logical within the context of the passage.

content:
The following passage is from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa society, at Cambridge University, August 31, 1837, entitled "The American Scholar."

The pronoun "this" in the last sentence of the passage refers to

answers.A: <label>A. But they can only highly serve us when they aim not to drill, but to create …</label>
answers.B: <label>B. History and exact science he must learn by laborious reading.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. Thought and knowledge are natures in which apparatus and pretension avail nothing.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Forget this, and our American colleges will recede in their public importance …</label>
answers.E: <label>E. When the mind is braced by labor and invention, the page of whatever book we read becomes luminous with manifold allusion.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Antecedents come before the given pronoun, and as close as possible to that pronoun. With this in mind, the fifth sentence of paragraph 3 is the only choice that correctly and logically fits the criteria.

content:
The following passage is from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa society, at Cambridge University, August 31, 1837, entitled "The American Scholar."

According to the speaker, the characteristics of the discerning reader include all of the following except:
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E If you pay close attention to the second paragraph, you will find all the choices, except E.

content:
The following passage is from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa society, at Cambridge University, August 31, 1837, entitled "The American Scholar."

Paragraphs 1 and 2 develop their ideas by means of

I. metaphor and simile

II. allusion

III. paradox
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Emerson alludes to “great English poets” in the first paragraph, and to a proverb and other writers in the second paragraph. Similes and metaphors can be found throughout both paragraphs, but no paradox is evident.

content:
The following passage is from Ralph Waldo Emerson’s Oration before the Phi Beta Kappa society, at Cambridge University, August 31, 1837, entitled "The American Scholar."

The purpose of the third paragraph is to

answers.C: <label>C. delineate the qualities of an ideal college</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Because this is an analytical passage, including the final paragraph, C is the only acceptable choice.

content:
The following excerpt is from Joseph Conrad’s The Secret Sharer.

Within the passage, the long, sinuous sentences emphasize the
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The very nature of sentences that are long and flowing serves to create a corresponding mood of passivity, ease, and timelessness. This lack of tension in the structure is not indicated in any of the other choices.

content:
The following excerpt is from Joseph Conrad’s The Secret Sharer.

In the next to last sentence of the passage (lines 21–24), "devious curves" most likely is used to reinforce

answers.B: <label>B. the hidden nature of the stream</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the concept of the complexity of what lies beneath the surface of the story</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Each of the choices deals with what is yet unknown to the narrator and the reader. The phrase “devious curves” foreshadows the complexity of the novella itself.

content:
The following excerpt is from Joseph Conrad’s The Secret Sharer.

The passage as a whole can best described as
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C This exemplifies that choosing the correct answer can be dependent on the student’s knowing definitions of terms and ability to recognize them in context. No other choice is acceptable in characterizing this passage.

content:
The following excerpt is from Joseph Conrad’s The Secret Sharer.

The first sentence of the passage helps to establish tone by means of

answers.A: <label>A. structure that reflects the strangeness of the experience described</label>
answers.B: <label>B. parallel structure that contrasts with the chaos of the situation</label>
answers.D: <label>D. irony to create a sense of satire</label>
answers.E: <label>E. hyperbole that exaggerates the danger of the situation</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A This compound-complex sentence sets the task for the reader with its convoluted structure and imagery. This reflects the very essence the narrator is presenting to the reader of the strangeness of the experience.

content:
The following excerpt is from Joseph Conrad’s The Secret Sharer.

Which of the following ideas can be supported based on the third sentence (lines 9–12) beginning with "And when I …"?

answers.A: <label>A. The speaker enjoys watching boats sailing on the horizon.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The speaker wants to revel in the beauty and grace of nature.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The speaker responds to the symmetry and balance of nature.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. The speaker realizes how vulnerable man is in the universe.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. The speaker is fearful of the earth and sea.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The diction, which includes “joined,” “edge to edge,” and “half brown, half blue,” supports the idea of balance and corresponding symmetry.

content:
The following excerpt is from Joseph Conrad’s The Secret Sharer.

All of the following contribute to the feeling of solitude except:

answers.A: <label>A. … the impassive earth had swallowed her up without an effort …</label>
answers.C: <label>C. the grove surrounding the great Paknam pagoda</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the monotonous sweep of the horizon</label>
answers.E: <label>E. ruins of stone walls, towers, and blockhouses</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Choices A, B, D, and E all reinforce the feeling of abandonment and aloneness. Choice C does not contribute to this impression of isolation; it is rather just a descriptive detail.

content:
The following excerpt is from Joseph Conrad’s The Secret Sharer.

The passage is organized primarily by means of
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A By its very definition, spatial description will provide the reader an opportunity to sense the setting by means of directions, scale, dimension, and color.

content:
The following excerpt is from Joseph Conrad’s The Secret Sharer.

In the third to last sentence of the passage (lines 18–21) beginning with "Here and there . . . ," the figure of speech used to describe "the windings of the great river" is
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Just find the word as , and you will easily locate the simile comparing the light to scattered pieces of silver.

content:
The following excerpt is from Joseph Conrad’s The Secret Sharer.

The writer emphasizes his solitude by using all of the following rhetorical techniques except:

answers.A: <label>A. heavy descriptive emphasis placed on setting</label>
answers.B: <label>B. overt statement of the absence of other people</label>
answers.C: <label>C. tracking the departure of the tugboat</label>
answers.D: <label>D. diction that emphasizes desertion and neglect</label>
answers.E: <label>E. contrasting the present situation with previous times</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E A careful reading of the passage uncovers each of the given choices except E. Nowhere in the excerpt does the narrator indicate a contrast between the current situation and a previous one.

content:
The following excerpt is from Joseph Conrad’s The Secret Sharer.

A characteristic of the author's style is
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The passage contains no allusions, has no real emotional diction, and maintains a constant first person point of view. And, most obviously, it does not rely on short, direct sentences. Therefore, the only choice is D.

content:
The following excerpt is from Joseph Conrad’s The Secret Sharer.

The tone of the passage can best be described as
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The entire passage involves the reader in the narrator’s thoughtful and reflective observations about his or her surroundings.

content:
The following passage is from Annie Dillard, What an Essay Can Do.

Which technique does the author employ to focus the reader's attention on the specific topic of the passage?

answers.C: <label>C. beginning each paragraph with the same subject</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Each paragraph opens with the words “the essay.” With this repetition, Dillard guarantees that the reader’s focus does not waver. It also provides the organizational framework of the passage. There is no passive voice present. (By the way, the previous sentence is an example of passive voice.) The author relates no personal narrative and does not identify herself with her audience.

content:
The following passage is from Annie Dillard, What an Essay Can Do.

Based on a careful reading of the first paragraph, the reader can conclude that the author blames the death of the "novel of idea" on
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E In the first two sentences, the author blames “contrived entrances” for killing “the novel of idea.” She supports this in the next to the last sentence in paragraph 1 by criticizing “fabricated dramatic occasions.” Both of these examples point to the artificial construct of fiction.

content:
The following passage is from Annie Dillard, What an Essay Can Do.

The primary rhetorical strategy the author uses to develop the first paragraph is
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The first paragraph contains two major cause-and-effect situations. The first is found in sentences 1–3, and the second is found in the last two sentences.

content:
The following passage is from Annie Dillard, What an Essay Can Do.

Near the end of the third paragraph, Dillard states, "The essayist does what we do with our lives; the essayist thinks about actual things. He can make sense of them analytically or artistically." The most probable reason for the author choosing to write two separate sentences rather than constructing a single, longer sentence using a listing, is

answers.B: <label>B. both subjects are of equal importance, although separate processes</label>
answers.E: <label>E. to highlight the criticism of fictional writing</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The first of the two sentences states what the essayist does: he thinks. The second sentence tells the reader how he thinks and writes. By writing two separate sentences, Dillard reinforces the equal importance of each of these points.

content:
The following passage is from Annie Dillard, What an Essay Can Do.

In paragraph 3, in the sentence beginning with "The real world …," the word "there" refers to
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D A careful reading of the sentence and a knowledge of how to locate antecedents can only lead the reader to choose “the real world.” Any other choice negates the correct meaning of antecedent/referent.

content:
The following passage is from Annie Dillard, What an Essay Can Do.

The primary rhetorical strategy the author uses to develop the second paragraph is
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The second paragraph clearly develops its point through a contrast and comparison between prose and poetry. None of the other strategies is present in the paragraph.

content:
The following passage is from Annie Dillard, What an Essay Can Do.

In terms of her position on her subject, the author can best be categorized as
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Dillard’s subject is the essay. Her position is one of unswerving allegiance to its form and function. Nowhere does she criticize the essay or the essayist, and nowhere does she discuss innovations or the changing of its form. Dillard is an artist. This classification, however, does not reveal her stance on the essay form.

content:
The following passage is from Annie Dillard, What an Essay Can Do.

An example of parallel structure is found in which of the following lines taken from the passage?

answers.A: <label>A. But eschewing it served to limit fiction's materials a little further, and likely contributed to our being left with the short story of scant idea.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. The essay may deal in metaphor better than the poem can, in some ways, because prose may expand what the lyric poem must compress.</label>
answers.C: <label>C. The elements in any nonfiction should be true not only artistically—the connections must hold at base …</label>
answers.D: <label>D. … that is the convention and the covenant between the nonfiction writer and his reader.</label>
answers.E: <label>E. In either case he renders the real world coherent and meaningful; even if only bits of it, and even if that coherence and meaning reside only inside small texts.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Knowing the definition of parallel structure and being able to recognize it makes the choice of E an easy one. (“Even if … even if …”)

content:
The following passage is from Annie Dillard, What an Essay Can Do.

The contrast between the short story writer and the essayist is based on which of the following?
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Look carefully at sentences 1–3 of paragraph 3 and notice the author’s use of the words “connections,” “covenant,” “veracity,” and “truth.” With this specific diction, the only appropriate choice is C.

content:
The following passage is from Annie Dillard, What an Essay Can Do.

The tone of the passage can best be described as
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E The only choice that contains two adjectives that are BOTH applicable to the author’s tone in this passage is E. The purpose of the essay is to inform/explain the function of the essay and the essayist. This, in itself, is the support for choosing E. The confidence is apparent in the writer’s discussion of the other forms of literature.

content:
Questions are based on the following passage in which Henry James responds to a literary critic’s ideas about the state of the English novel.
There is one point at which the moral sense and the artistic sense lie very near together; that is in the light of the very obvious truth that the deepest quality of a work of art will always be the quality of the mind of the producer. In proportion as that intelligence is fine will the novel, the picture, the statue partake of the substance of beauty and truth. To be constituted of such elements is, to my vision, to have purpose enough. No good novel will ever proceed from a superficial mind; that seems to me an axiom which for the artist in fiction, will cover all needful moral ground: if the youthful aspirant take it to heart it will illuminate for him many of the mysteries of "purpose." There are many other useful things that might be said to him, but I have come to the end of my article, and can only touch them as I pass. The critic in the Pall Mall Gazette, whom I have already quoted, draws attention to the danger, in speaking of the art of fiction, of generalizing. The danger that he has in mind is rather, I imagine, that of particularizing. I should remind the ingenuous student first of the magnificence of the form that is open to him, which offers to sight so few restrictions and such innumerable opportunities. The other arts, in comparison, appear confined and hampered; the various conditions under which they are exercised are so rigid and definite. But the only condition that I can think of attaching to the composition of the novel is, as I have already said, that it be sincere. This freedom is a splendid privilege, and the first lesson of the young novelist is to learn to be worthy of it. "Enjoy it as it deserves," I should say to him; "take possession of it, explore it to its utmost extent, publish it, rejoice in it. All life belongs to you, and do not listen either to those who would shut you up into corners of it and tell you that it is only here and there that art inhabits, or to those who would persuade you that this heavenly messenger wings her way outside of life altogether, breathing superfine air, and turning away her head from the truth of things. There is no impression of life, no manner of seeing it and feeling it, to which the plan of the novelist may not offer a place; you have only to remember that talents so dissimilar as those of Alexander Dumas and Jane Austen, Charles Dickens and Gustave Flaubert have worked in this field with equal glory. Do not think too much about optimism and pessimism; try and catch the color of life itself. If you must indulge in conclusions, let them have the taste of a wide knowledge. Remember that your first duty is to be as complete as possible—to make as perfect a work. Be generous and delicate and pursue the prize. (1884)

James draws a distinction between the purpose of the novel and
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C This is located in the first sentence. Here James tells his audience that the quality of the mind of the producer is the key factor in creating high-quality art. The moral and artistic grow out of this quality. “Obvious truth” refers to his premise, and beauty is a by-product of the process.

From the opening of the passage, it is clear that the author's attitude toward the creation of a work of art is
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E James’s diction is indicative of an elitist attitude. Note phrases such as “No good novel will ever proceed from a superficial mind …” He closes out any other possibility for a creative endeavor of quality.

According to James, beauty and truth are directly related to
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

B The question demands your close attention to the structure of the sentence. In this instance, beauty as truth is directly proportionate to intelligence. “This” applies to the novel, picture, statue. And, it is James’s vision.

According to the fourth sentence, the word "axiom" can best be defined as

explanation:

The critic in the Pall Mall Gazette, whom I have already quoted, draws attention to the danger, in speaking of the art of fiction, of generalizing. The danger that he has in mind is rather, I imagine, that of particularizing. I should remind the ingenuous student first of the magnificence of the form that is open to him, which offers to sight so few restrictions and such innumerable opportunities. The other arts, in comparison, appear confined and hampered; the various conditions under which they are exercised are so rigid and definite. But the only condition that I can think of attaching to the composition of the novel is, as I have already said, that it be sincere. This freedom is a splendid privilege, and the first lesson of the young novelist is to learn to be worthy of it. "Enjoy it as it deserves," I should say to him; "take possession of it, explore it to its utmost extent, publish it, rejoice in it. All life belongs to you, and do not listen either to those who would shut you up into corners of it and tell you that it is only here and there that art inhabits, or to those who would persuade you that this heavenly messenger wings her way outside of life altogether, breathing superfine air, and turning away her head from the truth of things. There is no impression of life, no manner of seeing it and feeling it, to which the plan of the novelist may not offer a place; you have only to remember that talents so dissimilar as those of Alexander Dumas and Jane Austen, Charles Dickens and Gustave Flaubert have worked in this field with equal glory. Do not think too much about optimism and pessimism; try and catch the color of life itself. If you must indulge in conclusions, let them have the taste of a wide knowledge. Remember that your first duty is to be as complete as possible—to make as perfect a work. Be generous and delicate and pursue the prize. (1884)

According to Henry James, the freest form of art is
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The sentence in the middle of the passage beginning with “The other arts …” will indicate to the careful reader that James is making a point to the student that art forms other than the novel are “confined and hampered.” No other choice is appropriate in this context.

content:
Questions are based on the following passage in which Henry James responds to a literary critic’s ideas about the state of the English novel.
There is one point at which the moral sense and the artistic sense lie very near together; that is in the light of the very obvious truth that the deepest quality of a work of art will always be the quality of the mind of the producer. In proportion as that intelligence is fine will the novel, the picture, the statue partake of the substance of beauty and truth. To be constituted of such elements is, to my vision, to have purpose enough. No good novel will ever proceed from a superficial mind; that seems to me an axiom which for the artist in fiction, will cover all needful moral ground: if the youthful aspirant take it to heart it will illuminate for him many of the mysteries of "purpose." There are many other useful things that might be said to him, but I have come to the end of my article, and can only touch them as I pass. The critic in the Pall Mall Gazette, whom I have already quoted, draws attention to the danger, in speaking of the art of fiction, of generalizing. The danger that he has in mind is rather, I imagine, that of particularizing. I should remind the ingenuous student first of the magnificence of the form that is open to him, which offers to sight so few restrictions and such innumerable opportunities. The other arts, in comparison, appear confined and hampered; the various conditions under which they are exercised are so rigid and definite. But the only condition that I can think of attaching to the composition of the novel is, as I have already said, that it be sincere. This freedom is a splendid privilege, and the first lesson of the young novelist is to learn to be worthy of it. "Enjoy it as it deserves," I should say to him; "take possession of it, explore it to its utmost extent, publish it, rejoice in it. All life belongs to you, and do not listen either to those who would shut you up into corners of it and tell you that it is only here and there that art inhabits, or to those who would persuade you that this heavenly messenger wings her way outside of life altogether, breathing superfine air, and turning away her head from the truth of things. There is no impression of life, no manner of seeing it and feeling it, to which the plan of the novelist may not offer a place; you have only to remember that talents so dissimilar as those of Alexander Dumas and Jane Austen, Charles Dickens and Gustave Flaubert have worked in this field with equal glory. Do not think too much about optimism and pessimism; try and catch the color of life itself. If you must indulge in conclusions, let them have the taste of a wide knowledge. Remember that your first duty is to be as complete as possible—to make as perfect a work. Be generous and delicate and pursue the prize. (1884)

In the middle of the passage, the sentence " 'Enjoy it as it deserves,' I should say to him; 'take possession of it, explore it to its utmost extent, publish it, rejoice in it,' " includes an example of
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B It is easy to see the parallel structure in this sentence. Notice “enjoy it”; “explore it”; “publish it”; “rejoice in it.” The other choices are not present.

In the second half of the passage, if the student follows the logic and advice of James in the set of sentences beginning with "This freedom is a splendid …" and ending with "the truth of things," that student would have to

answers.C: <label>C. recognize that only after death can a writer be assessed properly</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D This question may seem daunting at first, but careful examination of the structure of the lines reveals that James is telling the student not to allow himself to be cornered into following advice that limits his horizons. Ironically, James has already limited the scope of art and the artist.

Also in the middle of the passage is a sentence beginning with "All life belongs …" and ending with "the truth of things." The metaphor, "this heavenly messenger," contained in this sentence refers to
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The pronoun “this” in the middle of the sentence beginning with “All life belongs to you …” is your best clue to the answer “This” is referring to the word “art.” Therefore, the only appropriate choice is D.

content:
