The overall tone of the passage can best be described as
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C Through both the process of elimination and recognizing that both parts of your answer must be correct, the only appropriate choice is didactic, because the author is attempting to instruct the young novelist and exhortative in his urging the young writer to “catch the color of life itself.”

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

The controlling analogy of the passage is
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Throughout the passage, Melville builds his description on the comparison between items connected to the sea and those related to the land. Choices A and C are examples of this controlling analogy. D is another specific detail provided, and E is an example used by Melville to reinforce his description of the Nantucketer.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

Melville describes Nantucketers as all of the following except:

answers.E: <label>E. exploiters of the Native American claims</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E Paragraph 4 supports choices A, B, C, and D. The only choice not supported in the text is E.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

The tone of the passage can best be described as
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The diction and selection of detail all support the tone of admiration. The hyperbole can easily be seen in paragraph 1 and the end of paragraph 3.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

The most probable reason for repeating and italicizing "There" in the middle of paragraph 4 at the beginning of two main clauses in the same sentence is to

answers.A: <label>A. force the reader to look for an antecedent</label>
answers.C: <label>C. provide a break in a long, complicated sentence</label>
answers.E: <label>E. indicate sympathy for the plight of the Nantucketer</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Italics are used for very definite reasons. The purpose here is for emphasis. Melville wants to draw the reader back to the only other italicized word in the piece—Nantucket —the very first word of the passage.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

The shift in the focus of the piece occurs in which line?
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Here, pronouns are very important. In paragraph 2, this refers the reader to paragraph 1, which is about the island. These in paragraph 4 refers to the previous paragraph, which is about the inhabitants of Nantucket. The last sentence of the passage, while quite moving, indicates, again, a reference to Nantucketers. However, these in the first sentence of paragraph 3 is a definite shift in focus from the island to its inhabitants.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

The first paragraph contains an extended example of
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A The only choice appearing in the first paragraph is parallel structure, which is used throughout the listing of “extravaganzas” that Melville bestows on Nantucket. Many of the items in the listing begin with the word that .

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

Melville retells the Native American legend of how the island was settled in order to

answers.A: <label>A. have his audience identify with the Native American population</label>
answers.B: <label>B. make the passage seem like a parable</label>
answers.C: <label>C. contrast with the reality of the Nantucketers</label>
answers.D: <label>D. bring a mythic quality to the subject</label>
answers.E: <label>E. highlight the plight of the Nantucketers</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D Keeping in mind the central focus of the passage, Melville’s retelling of the Native American legend is not to highlight or focus on Native Americans, but to reinforce his attitude toward the Nantucketers, whom he perceives in mythic proportions. He compares them to Noah, to Alexander the Great, and to Emperors.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

The development of paragraph 3 is structured around
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The question requires the reader to be aware of the consecutive details that build in size and importance: from the clam to the whale.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

Based on a careful reading of the passage, complete the following analogy:NANTUCKET:ILLINOIS ::

answers.D: <label>D. backs of sea turtles:chairs and tables</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E The analogy established with Nantucket to Illinois is that of an island to a landlocked state. The only choice given that illustrates the same relationship is walrus to prairie dog. Here a walrus lives its life surrounded by the sea; whereas, the prairie dog is surrounded by the land.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

One may conclude from the information contained in paragraph 3 that "Himmalehan, salt-sea Mastedon" refers to
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B The whale is a “mightiest animated mass.” This can only refer to the largest creature in the sea. “Himmalehan” and “Mastadon” reinforce the power and size of the creature.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

The purpose of the passage is most probably to

answers.A: <label>A. encourage people to settle on Nantucket</label>
answers.B: <label>B. use Nantucket as a model of ecological conservation</label>
answers.C: <label>C. honor the indomitable spirit of the Nantucketers</label>
answers.D: <label>D. plead for the return of Nantucket to the Native Americans</label>
answers.E: <label>E. present a nostalgic reminiscence of the writer's birthplace</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The tone, diction, syntax, and selection of detail all point to Melville’s admiration of the fortitude, perseverance, and uniqueness of the Nantucketer.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

Melville uses thus twice in this passage: once in the second sentence of paragraph 2 to begin the Native American legend about the island being settled. What is the reason for using thus a second time in the first sentence of paragraph 4?

I. to begin a comparative legend with the Nantucketers settling the sea

II. to balance the first part of the passage with the second part

III. to reinforce the formality of his presentation
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D In this question, the repetition balances the dual focus: the island and its inhabitants. The diction and syntax of this selection are not formal, but rather a grand folk myth of epic proportions.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

The subtle humor of the first paragraph is dependent upon
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Beginning with “There is more sand” and continuing to the end of the paragraph, Melville presents examples dependent upon extreme exaggeration.

content:
The following passage is from Herman Melville’s "Moby-Dick."

The last sentence of the passage continues the analogy between
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E The paragraph develops an extended analogy that compares the world of the sea to that of the land, such as sea to prairie, sailor to prairie dog. None of the other choices are valid in this context.

content:
The following passage is from Lucy Stone, "A Disappointed Woman," a speech she gave to the national women’s rights convention in Cincinnati, Ohio, in October, 1855.

The tone of the passage can best be described as
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D If you chose E, you’re out of our class for the day. Seriously, it is obvious that the speaker both is outraged about the treatment of women and demands the right of women to be recognized. No other choice is correct in both descriptions.

content:
The following passage is from Lucy Stone, "A Disappointed Woman," a speech she gave to the national women’s rights convention in Cincinnati, Ohio, in October, 1855.

A major hypothesis presented by the speaker is that

answers.A: <label>A. religion is the cause of women's position in the United States</label>
answers.B: <label>B. women are not as intelligent as men</label>
answers.C: <label>C. education is the only way to cure the evils of society</label>
answers.D: <label>D. the question of Women's Rights is a philosophical issue</label>
answers.E: <label>E. women and African Americans are on the same level</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E The fifth sentence in paragraph 1 provides the answer to this question. In these two lines, the student should see that Stone makes a case that both women and blacks are not being educated and are by implication being treated in the same way.

content:
The following passage is from Lucy Stone, "A Disappointed Woman," a speech she gave to the national women’s rights convention in Cincinnati, Ohio, in October, 1855.

What can the reader infer based upon the sentence found in the middle of paragraph 1 that begins with "I was disappointed …" and ending with "and the housekeeper"?

answers.A: <label>A. Lucy Stone is not a religious person.</label>
answers.B: <label>B. Teaching was not considered a worthy profession.</label>
answers.D: <label>D. Stone values the opinions of others.</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B If the student carefully looks at the sixth sentence in paragraph 1, he or she will see that it is valid to conclude that the speaker does not hold teaching in high esteem.

content:
The following passage is from Lucy Stone, "A Disappointed Woman," a speech she gave to the national women’s rights convention in Cincinnati, Ohio, in October, 1855.

The theme of the passage is best expressed in
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Each of these lines plays an important role in the speech. However, only one plays the role of controlling the entire thought process. The other choices are subtopics.

content:
The following passage is from Lucy Stone, "A Disappointed Woman," a speech she gave to the national women’s rights convention in Cincinnati, Ohio, in October, 1855.

Stone develops her speech using all of the following except:
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Anecdotal support is found in the first six sentences of paragraph 1. A direct quotation is located in the second half of paragraph 2. Facts are used in the fourth and fifth sentences of paragraph 1, and the appeal to emotion is presented in the seventh sentence of paragraph 2. There is no ad hominem argument in the speech.

content:
The following passage is from Lucy Stone, "A Disappointed Woman," a speech she gave to the national women’s rights convention in Cincinnati, Ohio, in October, 1855.

In light of the passage, how can the following sentence near the end of the first paragraph best be characterized? "It shall be the business of my life to deepen this disappointment in every woman's heart until she bows down to it no longer."
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A Stone wants women to rise up and stop the oppression of their gender. But, according to this statement, she must actually see to it that women are oppressed until they can no longer bear it. It is only then that Stone sees their being willing to demand their rights.

content:
The following passage is from Lucy Stone, "A Disappointed Woman," a speech she gave to the national women’s rights convention in Cincinnati, Ohio, in October, 1855.

Based on a careful reading of the passage, one can assume that the speaker

answers.A: <label>A. believes that women are superior to men</label>
answers.B: <label>B. believes that religion is the salvation of women</label>
answers.D: <label>D. believes that foreign countries are more enlightened about women's rights than the United States</label>
answers.E: <label>E. is disappointed with her female contemporaries</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E If you look carefully at the section of the speech beginning with “I wish that women …” and ending with “frequent bar-rooms,” you will note that Stone says she is disappointed that women concern themselves only with the superficial. Her remarks about religion, foreign countries, fate, and men are in opposition to the actual choices. Notice the use of the word ephemeral .

content:
The following passage is from Lucy Stone, "A Disappointed Woman," a speech she gave to the national women’s rights convention in Cincinnati, Ohio, in October, 1855.

In the sentence beginning with "Wendell Phillips says …" in the middle of paragraph 2, Lucy Stone develops her point using
explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C The speaker aims for a logical conclusion when she points to Phillips’ definition of sphere. She creates an implied syllogism that if God cannot make a mistake, if God created each of us to do our best, this must apply to all—men and women alike.

content:
The following passage is from Lucy Stone, "A Disappointed Woman," a speech she gave to the national women’s rights convention in Cincinnati, Ohio, in October, 1855.

The speaker's purpose is most probably to
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B To exhort: to urge, to warn earnestly. In her speech, Lucy Stone is urging her audience to begin to stand up for their rights as women. She wants them to understand what is oppressing them and, as a result, to “no longer bow down to it.” A careful reading of the passage will indicate that the basis for the speech is NOT telling a story, nor is there an attempt to amuse or describe. The last sentence provides the final impetus for her exhortation.

content:
The following excerpt is from a review and discussion by Christopher Jencks of American Dream: Three Women, Ten Kids, and a Nation’s Drive to End Welfare, written by Jason DeParle and published by Viking/Penguin in 2005. The review appeared in the December 15, 2005, edition of The New York Review of Books.

The essence of the argument presented in this passage can be found in lines
explanation:
Correct Answer: E

Explanation:

E The argument is derived from the examples presented in the other choices.

content:
The following excerpt is from a review and discussion by Christopher Jencks of American Dream: Three Women, Ten Kids, and a Nation’s Drive to End Welfare, written by Jason DeParle and published by Viking/Penguin in 2005. The review appeared in the December 15, 2005, edition of The New York Review of Books.

The organizational pattern of the passage is
explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B Each paragraph provides specific statistics to support the claim that welfare reform is not a complete success. This thesis is presented at the end of the passage, NOT at the beginning.

content:
The following excerpt is from a review and discussion by Christopher Jencks of American Dream: Three Women, Ten Kids, and a Nation’s Drive to End Welfare, written by Jason DeParle and published by Viking/Penguin in 2005. The review appeared in the December 15, 2005, edition of The New York Review of Books.

The reader may infer from lines 35–38 that the writer

answers.A: <label>A. believes welfare is clearly a success</label>
answers.B: <label>B. believes welfare is failing to meet dismal situations</label>
answers.C: <label>C. admires the welfare programs of countries other than those of the United States</label>
answers.D: <label>D. maintains that there has been little need for welfare reform since 1996</label>
answers.E: <label>E. believes that the goals of the United States are the proper ones</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

C There is an indictment of the United States for failing to enact the policies and meet the goals that other countries have already put into practice.

content:
The following excerpt is from a review and discussion by Christopher Jencks of American Dream: Three Women, Ten Kids, and a Nation’s Drive to End Welfare, written by Jason DeParle and published by Viking/Penguin in 2005. The review appeared in the December 15, 2005, edition of The New York Review of Books.

The tone of the passage can best be described as
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A A cursory look at the inclusion and preponderance of statistics and other data with little personal commentary support this choice.

content:
The following excerpt is from a review and discussion by Christopher Jencks of American Dream: Three Women, Ten Kids, and a Nation’s Drive to End Welfare, written by Jason DeParle and published by Viking/Penguin in 2005. The review appeared in the December 15, 2005, edition of The New York Review of Books.

Which of the given footnotes is a primary source?
explanation:
Correct Answer: A

Explanation:

A All other footnotes cite sources, depend on other sources, or are personal commentary.

content:
The following excerpt is from a review and discussion by Christopher Jencks of American Dream: Three Women, Ten Kids, and a Nation’s Drive to End Welfare, written by Jason DeParle and published by Viking/Penguin in 2005. The review appeared in the December 15, 2005, edition of The New York Review of Books.

A critical reader of this passage should ask all of the following questions about footnote 7 except:

answers.A: <label>A. What is the relationship between Swingle and the author of this review?</label>
answers.B: <label>B. How many estimates were actually constructed?</label>
answers.D: <label>D. What are Swingle's qualifications as a reliable source?</label>
answers.E: <label>E. Can I locate an annotated citation about Swingle in another section of this review?</label>

explanation:
Correct Answer: B

Explanation:

B It doesn’t matter how many estimates there are. What is important is the authority and reliability of Swingle.

content:
The following excerpt is from a review and discussion by Christopher Jencks of American Dream: Three Women, Ten Kids, and a Nation’s Drive to End Welfare, written by Jason DeParle and published by Viking/Penguin in 2005. The review appeared in the December 15, 2005, edition of The New York Review of Books.

Another effective means of presenting the statistical material found in this passage would most probably be a(n)
explanation:
Correct Answer: D

Explanation:

D The presentation of so many statistics from various years demands a visual representation for clarity and ease of understanding. The other choices would only address a subjective aspect of the topic.
